intro: Angelica macrophylla, commonly known as the giant angelica, is a striking member of the Apiaceae family. It is native to the temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including parts of Europe, Asia, and North America. This plant is characterized by its large, broad leaves that can reach up to 30 centimeters in length, and its tall, branched stems that can grow up to 3 meters high. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in umbrella-like clusters, which are typical of the carrot family. Angelica macrophylla is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used historically in traditional medicine.
